HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

{ REPORT
{ No. 1429

TO RECOGNIZE THE HIGH PUBLIC SERVICE RENDERED BY MAJ.
WALTER REED AND THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH HIM IN THE DIS-
COVERY OF THE CAUSE AND MEANS OF TRANSMISSION OF
YELLOW FEVER

APRIL 30, 1928.--Committed to the Committee of the Whole House and ordered
to be printed

Mr. FROTHINGHAM, from the Committee on Military Affairs, sub-
mitted the following
REPORT
[To accompany H. R. 13060]

The Committee on Military Affairs, to whom was referred the bill
(H. R. 13060) to recognize the high public service rendered by Maj.
Walter Reed and those associated with him in the discovery of the
cause and means of transmission of yellow fever, introduced by Mr.
Wainwright, having considered the same, report thereon with the
recommendation that it do pass, with the following amendment:

Page 2, line 18, after the word “Lazear” insert the words “Mrs.
William Crawford Gorgas”.

Hearings were held on a similar bill (H. R. 11686) on April 11,
1928, and the following preliminary statement was made by the
Surgeon General of the Army, Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland:

Mr. Chairman and gentlemen, I am very glad to appear before the committee
in support of this bill, because my distinguished predecessor, Gen. Robert M.
O'Reilly, the greatest surgeon general that the Army ever had, made a similar
recommendation as far back as 1905. He prepared a memorandum which was
sent to the President, and which was forwarded to the Congress with this
comment:

“The inclosed papers are transmitted to the Congress in the hope that it will
take suitable action in this matter. Major Reed's part in the experiments
which resulted in teaching us how to cope with yellow fever was such as to
render mankind his debtor, and this Government should in some proper fashion
bear witness to this fact.

“THEODORE ROOSEVELT.
'DECEMBER 5, 1906.”

Walter Reed was the head of a board that went to Cuba in 1900 to discover,
if possible, the cause of yellow fever. By October, 1900, he had proven to his
own satisfaction that it was caused by the mosquito. This was proven to the
world very shortly afterwards, and in proving that yellow fever was transmitted
by a certain species of mosquito he made the greatest progress in preventive
medicine that had been made in the world up to that time; and I think it is a
2
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
very small thing for this Government to give a reward for those who were con-
nected with these experiments * * *.

The following complete statement of the circumstances attending
these investigations was prepared by Col. J. R. Kean, Medical Depart-
ment, United States Army, retired:

ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM,
Washington, D. C., April 18, 1928.

Hon. JOHN M. MORIN,
Chairman Committee on Military Affairs,
House of Representatives, Washington, D. C.

SIR: In compliance with the desires of your committee as expressed at the
hearing on April 11, 1928, on the bill H. R. 11686 for the reward of those taking
part in the work of the yellow fever board, I submit the following statement of
my connection with that work, and the names and status of those taking part in
it as requested of me by Hon. J. Mayhew Wainwright, who introduced the bill.

The yellow fever board or commission was organized and sent to Cuba by the
War Department upon the recommendation of Surgeon General Sternberg, in
June, 1900, to study the cause and prevention of yellow fever, a matter whose
vast importance, I believe, the committee well understands.

The members of the board were Maj. Walter Reed, surgeon United States
Army, Acting Assistant Surgeons James Carroll, Aristides Agramonte and
Jesse W. Lazear, United States Army. A statement with regard to each of them
is made below.

My connection with the work of this board, which was of no great importance
except that it permitted me to be familiar with all the details connected with
their work and to furnish information which may be of value to your committee,
arose from the following circumstances:

I had gone to Cuba in 1898 with the Seventh Corps, of which General Fitzhugh
Lee was the commanding general, and of which I became the chief surgeon.
After the discharge of the volunteers in May, 1899, General Lee was placed in
charge of the military department of western Cuba with headquarters at
Marianao. I was his chief surgeon with sanitary supervision of the area under
his command. The city of Habana was, however, excepted from his command,
being a separate military department under General Ludlow whose chief sanitary
officer was Maj. (afterwards major general) W. C. Gorgas. Major Reed and Doctor
Carroll arrived in Cuba June 25, 1900; the other two members of the commission,
Doctor Agramonte and Doctor Lazear, being already on duty in Cuba. In order
to secure quarters and office room without expense and a healthy environment
they received General Lee's permission to locate in certain buildings at the hos-
pital at Columbia Barracks, less than a mile from General Lee's headquarters.
This location permitted me, in my position, to be of service to the commission
in various ways, and I saw much of Major Reed, as we were old friends. It
appears to me unnecessary to recount the dramatic and interesting story of the
work of the board, as this is well covered in the first four chapters of Senate
Document 822, Sixty-first Congress, third session, entitled, “Yellow Fever, a
Compilation of Various Publications,” which the committee has resolved to
have reprinted. It will be sufficient to say that it may be divided into several
phases.

The first was the demonstration that there was no foundation in the claim of
Sanarelli that the Bacillus icteroides isolated by him was the cause of yellow fever.
This occupied the month of July. Then for sound epidemiological reasons the
board determined to investigate the theory of Dr. Carlos Finlay that yellow
fever was transmitted by a certain variety of mosquito. This second phase,
including the successful inoculations of Carroll and Pvt. Wm. H. Dean and the
tragic death of Doctor Lazear, includes the period to October 12 when Reed,
accompanied by me, had his interview with General Wood, which, by securing
General Wood's approval of experiments on human beings, and the grant of
money for necessary expenses, changed the whole character of the investigation.

Reed then went to the United States for a brief visit to consult with the Surgeon
General and read his paper, “The etiology of yellow fever, a preliminary note,”
at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association, October 22
to 26. Upon his return to Cuba, October 28, begins the third phase of his work,
occupied in the construction of an experimental station, Camp Lazear, and the
experiments thereat upon American Volunteers and Spanish immigrants, which
demonstrated the method of the transmission of yellow fever and made clear the
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
3
way of its prevention. This phase may be considered to have been completed
on February 4, 1901, when Reed read before the Pan American Medical Associa-
tion in Habana the report of the board, “The etiology of yellow fever, an addi-
tional note,” giving the results of their experiments and their conclusions.

After the adjournment of this meeting Reed and Carroll returned to Wash-
ington, and Gorgas gave a practical application of Reed's conclusions by warfare
upon mosquitoes in the city of Habana in accordance with the tenth conclusion
of the board which was:

“10. The spread of yellow fever can be most effectually controlled by measures
directed to the destruction of mosquitoes and the protection of the sick against
the bites of these insects.”

Doctor Carroll returned to Cuba during the fall of 1901 to make certain other
experiments connected with the etiology of yellow fever by the injection of
filtered blood from cases of that disease which demonstrated that the organism
of the disease was a “filterable virus” which would pass through a pasteur por-
celain filter, and was therefore ultramicroscopic in size.

STATEMENT WITH REGARD TO THE CLAIMS OF THE PERSONS NAMED IN THE BILL
WITH PERTINENT DATA CONCERNING THEM, FIRST CATEGORY

1. Mrs. Walter Reed was Emelie Lawrence, of North Carolina. Her family
came originally from Massachusetts, and was related to the distinguished bishop,
Right Rev. William Lawrence, of Massachusetts. They were married in 1876.
There were two children of this marriage, both of whom are living. Since the
death of Major Reed after an operation for appendicitis in Washington, November
23, 1902, she has not remarried, and is a resident of the city of Washington.

At the time of his death the Secretary of War, the Hon. Elihu Root, had pro-
posed in his annual report to the President that Reed being the senior major in
his grade should be promoted to the grade of colonel in the Medical Department
and that Maj. W. C. Gorgas should be promoted to the grade of lieutenant colonel.
This recommendation, although it had not been published, was known to the
writer, and Major Reed was told of it by him on his deathbed. He replied,
“I do not care for that now.” The special promotion to colonel was later given
to Major Gorgas.

With reference to the recognition of Reed's work by the United States Govern-
ment, Dr. Howard A. Kelly in his work “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
quotes at the beginning of Chapter X on the value of Doctor Reed's work to the
world as follows from the Bible, Book of Esther, 6:3, “And the King said what
honour and dignity have been done to Mordecai for this? Then said the King's
servants who ministered unto him, There is nothing done for him.”

The Surgeon General proposed that Major Reed's pay as major ($291 per
month) be continued to Mrs. Reed as a pension. A bill providing for this was
introduced into the Senate by Senator Martin of Virginia, and was passed with
the amount reduced to $125 per month. A similar bill was introduced into the
House by Mr. Maynard of Virginia, and was referred to the Pension Committee,
but never reported out by them. On the morning of March 4, 1903, by agreement
between the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House, and the Speaker,
Mr. Henderson, the Pension Committee was discharged from consideration of
the bill and the Senate bill was taken up and passed. The appropriations for
her annuity were made for some years on the War Department appropriation
bill, but payments are now made by the Pension Bureau.

Regarding the value of Major Reed's services to this country and to humanity
it is believed that the committee is well informed. I would, therefore, only
quote a paragraph from a letter of Prof. William H. Welch, of Johns Hopkins
University, written soon after Reed's death, to the Secretary of War, in which
he stated:

“Doctor Reed's researches in yellow fever are by far the most important
contributions to science which have ever come from an Army surgeon. In my
judgment, they are the most valuable contributions to medicine and public
hygiene which have ever been made in this country, with the exception of the
discovery of anaesthesia. They have led and will lead to the saving of thou-
sands of lives. I am in a position to know that the credit for the original ideas
embodied in this work belongs wholly to Major Reed.”

Major Reed left no property except a small life insurance, and the pension
received by Mrs. Reed is, as the committee must realize, quite inadequate for a
comfortable and dignified existence. This inadequacy has been made worse by
the depreciation in the purchasing power of the dollar due to the World War,
4
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
so that her pension now is about equivalent to one of $75 at the time it was
given. It has been helped out to some extent by payment to her of the interest
on a fund collected by a group of Major Reed's friends for the purpose of erecting
a monument to him. The principal of this fund will be available to assist in the
erection of a monument to him whenever the Government sees fit to make pro-
vision for one, provided that adequate support for Mrs. Reed has been made.

2. Mrs. James Carroll was the wife of Dr. James Carroll, by whom she had
seven children. Mrs. Carroll has, so far as is known to the writer, never re-
married. Her present address is box 2440, St. Petersburg, Fla. She has re-
ceived since soon after the death of Major Carroll on September 16, 1907, a
monthly pension of $125. Doctor Carroll was born in England and enlisted in
the Army June 9, 1874. He served in the grades of private, corporal, sergeant,
and hospital steward, first at western posts and later in New York and Washing-
ton. He took advantage of his opportunities as a medical department soldier to
study medicine, and being encouraged by the medical officers under whom he
served graduated at the University of Maryland in 1891. He then, in 1893,
became Major Reed's laboratory assistant at the Army Medical School in
Washington, where he served until his appointment as acting assistant surgeon,
May 21, 1898. He served as Major Reed's assistant in the investigation of the
typhoid-fever epidemic during the Spanish War, and, doubtless on his recommenda-
tion, was made a member of the Yellow Fever Board in 1900. He permitted
himself to be bitten by infected mosquitoes, and was the first experimental case
caused by the board, being taken sick August 31, 1900. In recognition of this
experience he was commissioned a first lieutenant and assistant surgeon in the
Medical Corps October 27, 1902. From this grade he was promoted to major by a
special act of Congress March 9, 1907. He died in Washington, D. C., of myo-
carditis September 16, 1907.

Mrs. Carroll's pension has been, of course, inadequate for her needs and those
of her family. This inadequacy has been much increased by the fall in the
purchasing power of the dollar since the World War.

3. Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear (Mabel M. Lazear) was the wife of Dr. Jesse W.
Lazear, acting assistant surgeon and third member of the yellow fever board.
At the time of his death at Camp Columbia, Cuba, September 25, 1900, of yellow
fever, incurred in the line of duty, they had two young children; the youngest of
these he never saw. She has not remarried and since his death has received
an annuity of $125 per month. It is understood that Doctor Lazear left very
little property and she had great difficulty in supporting herself and her children.
Her present address is 6 Oak Vale Avenue, Berkeley, Calif.

Jesse W. Lazear was born in Baltimore May 2, 1866. He graduated in medicine
at Columbia University, New York City, in 1892, after which he served two years
at Bellevue Hospital in New York. He then spent a year in Europe, a part of it
at the Pasteur Institute in Paris. On his return home he was made bacterio-
logist to the medical staff of Johns Hopkins Hospital, and was also assistant in
clinical microscopy in the university. He was one of the first men in this country
to study the development of the malarial organism in the blood of man and in the
mosquito, and this knowledge was of the greatest value to the yellow fever board
when they took up the study of that disease. He was a man not only of brilliant
professional attainments, who, but for his untimely death, would have gone far
in his profession, but of noble character and great personal charm. He and his
family have received no reward for his great services to the country except the
inadequate pension above mentioned, and the naming after him of a battery in
Baltimore Harbor.

4. Dr. Aristides Agramonte is the only living member of the yellow fever
commission. He was born in Cuba during the “ten years” war, in which his
father, a Cuban officer, was killed in battle by the Spaniards. The Agramonte
family came to New York when he was 10 years old, and he grew up and was
graduated in that city. He graduated in medicine at the College of Physicians
and Surgeons where he and Lazear were classmates. At the beginning of the
Spanish War he joined the Army as an acting assistant surgeon, and after the
American occupation, had charge of the Army medical laboratory in Habana.
Upon the organization of the yellow fever commission he was detailed as a member
of it, and contributed materially to its success. He performed most of the autopsy
work and the experiments on animals, and after Lazear's death had charge of the
mosquito work. He served with the Army until the establishment of the Cuban
Republic in May, 1902. Upon the withdrawal of the American forces he remained
in Habana and was appointed a professor in the medical school of the University
of Habana, a position which he still occupies. During the American government
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
5
of pacification in Cuba, 1906-1909 he was a member of the yellow fever board in
Habana, and rendered valuable service in the campaign against yellow fever which
had again broken out in Habana and spread over most of the island.

Doctor Agramonte has never received from the United States Government
any honor, recognition, or material reward for his distinguished services to this
country and to humanity as a member of the yellow fever commission. The
Cuban Government has recently set us an example in generosity by voting a
generous pension to the widow of General Leonard Wood. It would seem that
our country should in its turn recognize its debt to Dr. Aristides Agramonte who,
though now a Cuban, has worn our uniform and rendered us distinguished
service.

THE VOLUNTEERS WHO SUFFERED FROM EXPERIMENTAL YELLOW FEVER, SECOND
CATEGORY

The second category of persons to whom these United States is indebted for
the conquest of yellow fever consists of 14 names, 12 of whom were private
soldiers serving in Cuba. They are arranged in the bill in alphabetical order, and
will be considered in that order, as in the bill H. R. 11686.

5. John A. Andrus, private, Hospital Corps, volunteered and was infected with
yellow fever by injection of blood at Camp Lazear, January 28, 1901. He was
discharged from the military service April 24, 1902, at Camp George H. Thomas,
Chickamauga, Tenn.; character excellent. He was born at Fassett, Pa. His
present address is not known. Father's address, Seth C. Andrus, Elmira, N. Y.
He received a donation of $200, paid by the writer from Cuban funds granted by
the military governor, General Leonard Wood, but I understand does not receive
any pension from the United States.

6. Mr. John R. Bullard was a native of Massachusetts and a graduate of Har-
vard University, where he was a distinguished athlete; he came to Cuba in 1901,
where he purchased land and engaged in farming. In the fall of 1901 he became
ill with malarial fever, and was brought to Camp Columbia for treatment. He
was treated by Doctor Carroll, who interested him in the yellow-fever work, so
that after his recovery he offered himself as a volunteer for experiment. Doctor
Carroll infected him with yellow fever by the injection of blood, he being taken
sick October 23, 1901. In point of time he was the last of the series of experi-
mental cases. Mr. Bullard has not, I believe, received any reward or recognition
from the Government of the United States or the military government of Cuba.
His present address is Ingenio Jatibonico, Jatibonico, Oriente, Cuba.

7. Albert W. Covington, private, Twenty-third Company, Coast Artillery, was
born at Laurinsburg, N. C., enlisted at Maxton, N. C. He remained in the
service until August 9, 1926, when he was retired for long service. Address,
Mrs. Rose Covington, R. F. D. 3, Cohocton, N. Y.

He was one of the group of volunteers infected by Doctor Carroll by blood
injections in the fall of 1901. He received an injection of filtered blood serum
from a case of yellow fever, and became sick October 19, 1901. He received a
donation of $200 from the undersigned from the allotment of Cuban funds made
by General Wood for these experiments. He receives from the Government his
retired pay for long service, but no reward for his part in the yellow-fever work.

8. William H. Dean, private, Troop B, Seventh Cavalry, was born at Holland,
Ohio, enlisted at Grand Rapids, Mich., and was discharged August 17, 1902.
His present address is unknown.

The case of this soldier, which followed that of Doctor Carroll, was of great
importance as it convinced Major Reed of the truth of Doctor Finlay's mosquito-
transmission theory. He was infected on August 31, 1900, by the same mosquito
that had caused Doctor Carroll's illness, and on the same day that the diagnosis
of yellow fever in Doctor Carroll's case was made. His name was concealed at
the time under the anonymous designation “X. Y.” because the experiment was
made without military authorization at Columbia Barracks at a time when it
was under rigid quarantine against the introduction of yellow fever. He has
never received any reward from either the United States or from the Cuban
treasury.

9. Wallace W. Forbes, private, Hospital Corps, was born at Galesburg, Ill.;
enlisted at Minneapolis, Minn. He was discharged March 1, 1905, with character
excellent. The address of his mother whose name was not given on the record
was 1523 Irving Avenue, Minneapolis, Minn.

He volunteered to be infected with yellow fever by injection of blood at Camp
Lazear, and became sick January 24, 1901. He received a donation of $200 from
6
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments, but is not be-
lieved to have received any pension or other recognition from the United States.

10. Levi E. Folk, private, Hospital Corps, was born at Kadish, S. C.; he
enlisted at Columbia, S. C., and was retired for long service March 30, 1923.

Folk was one of the men who volunteered to undergo the very trying experience
of exposure to fomites by sleeping 20 nights in the bed clothing and body clothes
which had been used by yellow fever patients, and which was soiled with their
excretions.

It was obviously necessary to establish the fact that the men who underwent
this experiment were not immune, and Folk volunteered to be bitten by infected
mosquitoes, and was taken ill with yellow fever January 23, 1901.

He received a donation of $100 for the fomites experiment and $200 for the
yellow fever inoculation from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for
these experiments. He receives from the Government his retired pay but has
not, so far as is known, received any pension or other reward for his services as
a volunteer in these experiments. His present address is 374 South Third
Street, Columbus, Ohio.

11. Paul Hamann, private, Twenty-third Company, Coast Artillery, was
born in Germany and enlisted at Springfield, Ill. After long service he was
discharged August 12, 1913.

Hamann was one of the group of cases infected by Doctor Carroll in the fall
of 1901 by injection of filtered blood serum from a case of yellow fever. He
became sick October 19, 1901.

He received a donation of $200 from the Cuban funds allotted by General
Wood for these experiments, and he receives from the Government a pension of
$20 per month. Address, care of his father, August Hamann, East Moline, Ill.

Hanberry, like Folk, first underwent the fomites experiment, and then volun-
teered to be bitten by infected mosquitoes, and in consequence was taken sick
with yellow fever at Camp Lazear, February 9, 1901. He received donations
amounting to $300 from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these
experiments.

Being a deserter he has, naturally, not received any pension or reward from the
United States Government.

13. Mrs. Warren G. Jernegan (N. May Jernegan) is the widow of Warren G.
Jernegan, private, Hospital Corps, who was born at Cone, Fla. He was dis-
charged at Columbia Barracks, November 16, 1901, but afterwards was in the
Government employ at Panama, and, as stated by his widow, died February 5,
1919, while still in Government employ in Charleston, S. C.

He, like Folk and Hanberry, after undergoing the fomites experiment, volun-
teered to have his immunity tested by an injection of blood from a yellow-fever
patient, and was taken sick January 8, 1901.

For these two experiments he received donations amounting to $300 from the
Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments. Mrs. Jernegan
receives a pension of $125 per month from the United States Government.

14. JOHN R. KISSINGER, private, Hospital Corps, was born at McClure,
Ohio; enlisted for the Spanish War at Indianapolis, Ind. He was discharged
November 14, 1901, at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, with character excellent.

Kissinger with Moran, who will be next mentioned, were the first to volunteer
as subjects for experiment in the second phase of the work of the board. Moran
was first bitten, but Kissinger was the first to be infected and to suffer an attack
of yellow fever on December 8, 1900.

When promised a donation by Major Reed at the time he volunteered, Kis-
singer declined it stating he wished to undergo the experiment for the benefit of
science and humanity. After his recovery he was promoted to be acting hospital
steward, and was presented with a gold watch by the department surgeon at a
military ceremony. This watch was paid for from the donation to which he
was entitled, and he afterwards accepted the balance of the donation in money.
His health having failed he was on March 2, 1907, granted a pension of $12 per
month. On February 11, 1911 he was granted an annuity of $100 per month.
His present address is R. F. D. 8, Huntington, Ind.

15. Mr. John J. Moran was born in Ohio and served as a volunteer in the
Spanish War in the Seventh Army Corps. After his discharge he was employed
by the Army at the headquarters of General Fitzhugh Lee at Marianao, as a
clerk.

RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
7

Mr. Moran disclaimed before submitting to the experiments any desire for
reward, and has never accepted any, although he was offered the $200 from the
Cuban funds which the others received.

The first bites from infected mosquitoes received by him on November 26,
and 29 were, for some reason, unsuccessful. He was infected on the third attempt
on December 21 and came down with yellow fever on Christmas Day, 1900.

After leaving Cuba he completed his education by a course of study at the
University of Virginia, and then lived for a number of years in Panama in the
employ of the Isthmian Canal Commission. He is at present in Mexico in the
employment of the Firestone Tire Co., through which he can be communicated
with.

He has never received, nor, so far as is known, applied for any pension or
reward from either the Cuban Government or the Government of the United
States.

16. William Olsen, private, Hospital Corps, was born in Pierce County, Wis.;
enlisted for the Spanish War at Minneapolis, Minn., and was discharged Novem-
ber 15, 1901, with character excellent, his address being given as 7211 San Pedro
Street, Los Angeles, Calif.

He was infected with yellow fever by injection of blood at Camp Lazear and
taken sick January 11, 1901.

He received a donation of $200 from the Cuban funds allotted by General
Wood for these experiments. He is now in receipt of a pension from the Govern-
ment of $40 per month, presumably a Spanish pension.

17. Charles G. Sonntag, private, Hospital Corps, was born at Charleston, S. C.,
and enlisted at Camp Onward, Ga. He was discharged December 12, 1901, at
Columbia Barracks, with character very good.

He volunteered to be bitten by infected mosquitoes and was, in consequence,
taken sick with yellow fever at Camp Lazear, February 10, 1901. He received
a donation of $200 from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these
experiments, and is also at present in receipt of a pension of $50 per month.
His present address is rural route No. 3, Gaston, S. C.

18. Clyde L. West, private, Hospital Corps, was born at Mier, Ind., and enlisted
for the Spanish war at Toledo, Ohio. He was discharged July 10, 1902, at Fort
Myer, Va., character, very good.

West volunteered to be bitten by infected mosquitoes at Camp Lazear, and
was taken sick with yellow fever February 3, 1901. He received a donation of
$200 from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments, also
in 1927 was given a pension of $100 per month for his services as a volunteer in
the yellow fever work; he gets also a pension of $30 per month for his Spanish
war services.
VOLUNTEERS IN FOMITES EXPERIMENTS, THIRD CATEGORY

19. Dr. R. P. Cooke was born in Virginia in 1874. He volunteered for experi-
ment with fomites, and underwent the experiment with the first group who slept
in infected bedding. He had charge of all the men engaged in these experiments.
He entered the medical service of the Army June 9, 1900, as a contract surgeon
and was on duty in the hospital at Piner Del Rio during the yellow-fever epidemic
at that place in July, 1900. He left the service at his own request December 2,
1904. He received a donation of $100 from the Cuban funds allotted by General
Wood for these experiments, but has not received any recognition or pension
from the United States Government.

20. Thomas M. England, private, Hospital Corps, was born in Chillicothe,
Ohio, and served in the Army from January 6, 1899, to January 5, 1914, in the
grades of private, acting hospital steward, and sergeant, first class, Hospital
Corps. He again enlisted July 28, 1915, and served as sergeant, first class, and
hospital sergeant and master hospital sergeant to February 15, 1918. He was
then appointed first lieutenant Sanitary Corps in the National Army and served
until the end of the World War. He was commissioned captain Medical Admin-
istrative Corps in the regular service July 1, 1920, and is now serving in that
grade.

He volunteered and underwent the fomites experiment, sleeping 20 nights in
infected bedding, for which experiment he received a donation of $100 from the
Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments. He has not
received any pension or recognition from the United States Government. His
present address is care of the Surgeon General, War Department, Washington,
D. C.

8
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.

21. James Hildebrand, private, Hospital Corps, was born at Decatur, Ga.,
and enlisted at Savannah, Ga., for service in Cuba. He was discharged August
17, 1914, at Walter Reed General Hospital, Washington, D. C., with character
excellent.

Private Hildebrand underwent the fomites experiment, and then volunteered
to be bitten with infected mosquitoes. He was, however, rejected by Major
Reed for this experiment on account of his age, being over 40 years old. It is
well known that yellow fever is much more fatal at that age and later than with
young men.

He received a donation of $100 from Cuban funds allotted by General Wood
for these experiments. He is now in receipt of a pension from the United States
of $50 per month, which it is understood, is given him on account of long service
and ill health, and not for his participation in these experiments.
His present address is 412 Berean Street, Atlanta, Ga.

22. Edward Weatherwalks, private, Hospital Corps, was born at Pompton,
N. J., and enlisted for service in Cuba at Savannah, Ga., and was discharged
February 12, 1901, at Columbia Barracks with character good.

He underwent the fomites experiment and was bitten once by mosquitoes
without becoming infected. He afterwards declined further experiments. He
received a donation of $100 from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for
these experiments.

He died October 21, 1916, at Haskell, N. J.; his widow, Mrs. Lucy Weather-
walks, lives at Lenox Avenue, Pompton Lakes, N. J., and receives a pension of
$30 per month, presumably on account of her husband's service in the Spanish
War.
SPANISH IMMIGRANTS

In addition to the American volunteers enumerated above there were seven
Spanish immigrants who were employed to undergo these experiemnts. Their
engagement to do so was a purely business arrangement which was approved by
the Spanish consul at Habana; a signed contract was entered into with each one.
These men who had come to Cuba to get employment realized well the danger
of death of yellow fever, and it was explained to them that in undergoing these
experiments they would have the best medical care and nursing, and would be
paid what was to them a very large sum of money, $200 American gold at the
then rate of exchange being worth about 1,300 Spanish pesetas. The names of
these men are as follows:
Nicanor Fernandez, taken sick, December 13, 1900.
Antonio Benigno, taken sick, December 13, 1900.
Becente Presdeo, taken sick December 15, 1900.
Jose Martinez, taken sick January 3, 1901.
Pablo Ruiz Castillo, taken sick September 19, 1901.
Jacinto Mendez Alvarez, taken sick October 13, 1901.
Manuel Gutierrez Moran, taken sick October 20, 1901.

A wide distinction should, in my mind, be made between the payments to the
Spanish peasants employed by the board and the donations made to the American
soldiers who volunteered to take part in the experiments. In the latter case the
payment was regarded as a gratuity which was given in recognition of their
meritorious services in the same way that the increased pay was given to men
who had earned a certificate of merit by gallantry in action. The only interest
which the Spaniards took in the matter was to acquire immunity with the slightest
possible risk, and to get a handsome payment for their services. The Americans
on the contrary understood what it was all about and were tremenduously
interested in the importance to humanity of a successful result.
Respectfully submitted,

J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U. S. Army, Retired.

The following letter from the Secretary of War reporting on H. R.
11686, a similar bill, follows:

WAR DEPARTMENT,
Washington, April 18, 1928.

Hon. JOHN M. MORIN,
Chairman Committee on Military Affairs,
House of Representatives.

DEAR MR. MORIN: In compliance with the request of March 14, 1928, I am
pleased to submit herewith a report in duplicate from The Adjutant General on
H. R. 11686, Seventieth Congress, first session.

RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
9

The subject of so much of the proposed legislation as refers to the War De-
partment provides for the placing of the names of certain individuals on the rolls
of the department and also that, in special recognition of the high public serv-
ices rendered and disabilities contracted by them in the interest of humanity
and science as volunteer subjects for the experimentations during the yellow
fever investigations in Cuba, the Secretary of War be, and hereby is, authorized
and directed to pay to them during the remainder of their natural lives $250 per
month in lieu of all pensions now received.

The Congress has heretofore enacted legislation granting to Jennie Carroll,
widow of Maj. James Carroll, United States Army, to Mabel H. Lazear, widow
of Jesse W. Lazear, acting assistant contract surgeon, United States Army, and to
Mrs. Walter Reed, annuities of $125 per month; also to Clyde L. West, late of
United States Hospital Corps, and John R. Kissinger, United States Army,
annuities of $100 per month each, to revert to their widows, in recognition of
eminent services performed by these men in connection with the yellow fever
experimentation in Cuba; and provision for the payment of these annuities
except that to Mrs. Walter Reed, which is granted as a pension under a special
act approved March 3, 1903 (private 1118, 57th Cong., 2d sess.) and is paid by
the Pension Bureau, has been carried in the Army appropriation bills, and is
provided for in H. R. 10286, Seventieth Congress, first session, making appropria-
tion for the military and nonmilitary activities of the War Department for the
fiscal year ending June 30, 1929, approved March 23, 1928. It does not appear
from any evidence before the War Department that the cases of these four men
mentioned were of exceptional merit as compared with the cases of the other
participants in the experiments.

The names mentioned in the bill are, with the following exceptions, already
carried on the rolls of the War Department: Mrs. Walter Reed, Dr. Aristides
Agramonti, John R. Bullard, Mrs. Warren J. Jernegan, John J. Moran, and
Dr. R. P. Cooke. In the case of the last named (R. P. Cooke) H. R. 8772,
which passed the House of Representatives on January 11 last, would provide
payment at the rate of $100 a month. This bill has not become a law.

It will be noted that the present bill would raise the annuities from the $125
per month now being paid to Jennie Carroll and Mabel H. Lazear and also the
annuity of $100 per month now being paid to Clyde L. West and John R.
Kissinger, to $250 per month.

From the report of The Adjutant General it will be seen that there are omitted
from the bill the names of seven persons, Spaniards, who submitted themselves
to experiments in connection with the yellow fever investigation, namely:
Nicanor Fernandez, Antonio Benigno, Becente Presedo, Jose Martinez, Pablo
Ruiz Castillo, Jacinto Mendez Alvarez, and Manuel Gutierrez Moran. In con-
nection with these men it is deemed proper to call attention to the remarks made
by Surg. Gen. George H. Torney, United States Army, in a report of the occur-
rences which led to the appointment of the yellow fever commission as follows:

“Before taking up individually the men concerned in these experiments, in
order to state what is known about them at the present time, it may be men-
tioned that the Spaniards who were inoculated did so for the pecuniary induce-
ment offered them. After receiving the reward offered them by the liberality
of the military government of Cuba, $200 for each person successfully inocu-
lated, they passed from the scene and nothing further is known concerning them.
While their names should be preserved as a matter of historical interest, it is
considered that they have been well rewarded for their share in the matter,
especially as the idea of assisting in the advancement of science was not a con-
trolling motive for their action.”

Attention is called to the fact that James Hildebrand, whose name appears as
a beneficiary under the bill, while he generously offered himself as a subject, was
not accepted for inoculation by reason of minority.

Thomas M. England (whose name appears in the fourteenth line incorrectly
as Thomas H. England) is now a commissioned officer in the Army and will
probably at some time in the future come under the provisions of the retirement
law.

It is deemed proper to add that section 1 of the bill in reference is substantially
identical with H. R. 16669, Sixty-ninth Congress, second session, upon which
a report was made by The Adjutant General to the Secretary of War on Feb-
ruary 26, 1927, in response to the call of the chairman, Committee on Military
Affairs, House of Representatives.

It would seem that in equity the Government, in establishing rewards for
meritorious service, should consider the relative values of the services performed
10
RECOGNIZE PUBLIC SERVICE OF MAJ. WALTER REED ET AL.
and adopt, as nearly as may be, equal rewards for equal services; yet, while
the instant bill would pay to the beneficiaries thereunder $250 a month, section
3 of the act of Congress approved April 27, 1916 (H. R. 4701, Public No. 56,
64th Cong.), provides for payment to each surviving person, holder of the
congressional medal, whose name has been entered on the medal of honor roll,
who “in action involving actual conflict with the enemy, distinguished himself
conspicuously by gallantry or intrepidity, at the risk of his life beyond and
above the call of duty” a special pension of only $10 per month in addition to
any other pension he may be receiving.

It has been ascertained from the Commissioner of Pensions that under the
pension laws $125 per month is the highest pension paid under the pension
laws, and from the Veterans' Bureau that the highest compensation paid under
the World War veterans' act is $200 per month; both for total disability.

The difficulty of determining an adequate reward for services as great as
those performed by those persons who offered themselves for experimentation
in the yellow-fever investigation is recognized, but the facts having been stated
above, and as the War Department is not directly concerned, I feel that a decision
of the question should be left to the Congress as a matter of public policy.

Sincerely yours,
DWIGHT F. DAVIS, Secretary of War.
